note.body:
Yes, there are two external screens.

- ThinkPad T480s Notebook
- Razer Core X Chroma eGPU Connector connected via Thunderbolt over USB-C port
- Sapphire Nitro+ Radeon RX Vega 64 GPU
- 2x DELL 2515H screens directly connected to the GPU via DisplayPort

Hotplugging seems to work partially: all three screens appear in GNOME Settings (the integrated and both external screens) but the external screens are both still dark and in standby.

Here is a log from the hotplugging attempt:

events.target_title: Add CTRL+K shortcut to search with the default search engine
Add support for radialGradient 'fr' attribute from SVG2

note.body:
Hi Corentin,

Thanks for the effort. Worked on this issue but didn't find time to complete it. `fix_focus_point` is a requirement of SVG 1.1 which [changed in 2.0](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/pservers.html#RadialGradientNotes):

>  Changed in SVG 2. SVG 1.1 required that the focal point, if outside the end circle, be moved to be on the end circle. The change was made to align with Canvas.

It means the `fix_focus_point` function could be removed completely as per my research Cairo alone is doing what is expected. Explored the option to keep it: fix the focus point for SVG 1.x documents, don't fix it for 2.x, but determining the SVG version is a controversial topic - it existed as an attribute of `<svg>`, was ignored while it existed and then [got deprecated](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/version).

Since the SVG 2.x test suite is still work in progress didn't have an "official" way to test it, especially the cone example mentioned in [14.2.3.2. Notes on radial gradients](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/pservers.html#RadialGradientNotes).

Took the lower effort (apologies as it's not the cleanest example) and edited a SVG 2.x test attached below to fit the `#[test] fn fixes_focus_point()` example `// outside the circle` and rendered it in Firefox, Chrome and Safari. Chrome and Safari render it "properly" per SVG 2.0 spec, Firefox doesn't. Iirc, all 3 use different web engines.

Firefox:

![firefox](/uploads/e4f759b323749b8a8aa0f077ad44f701/firefox.png)

Chrome/Safari:

![chrome_safari](/uploads/7e53b4397aa226f4ec100f1f032fd107/chrome_safari.png)

Cairo, without calling `fix_focus_point` renders it as Chrome/Safari above.

As mentioned above, didn't find time to complete this, and guess the next step would be finding if someone reported this "bug"/spec compliance issue in the respective browsers. Also coming up with a cleaner example would be a nice start. Hope this helped.

The test SVG:

```
<svg id="svg-root"
  width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 480 360"
  xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
  xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
  xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <g id="testmeta">
    <title>Radial gradient: Basic three stop gradient with 'fr'.</title>
    <html:link rel="author"
          title="Tavmjong Bah"
          href="http://tavmjong.free.fr"/>
    <html:link rel="help"
          href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/pservers.html#RadialGradients"/>
    <html:link rel="match"  href="radialgradient-basic-002-ref.svg" />
  </g>

  <style id="test-font" type="text/css">
    /* Standard Font (if needed). */
    @font-face {
      font-family: FreeSans;
      src: url("../fonts/FreeSans.woff") format("woff");
    }
    text {
      font-family: FreeSans, sans-serif;
      text-anchor: middle;
      fill: black;
    }
    #title {
      font-size: 24px;
    }
    .label {
      font-size: 18px;
    }
  </style>

  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="RadialGradient1" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse" fx="100" fy="100" fr="100" cx="300" cy="100" r="100">
      <stop style="stop-color:#0000ff" offset="0%"/>
      <stop style="stop-color:#00ffff" offset="50%"/>
      <stop style="stop-color:#ffff00" offset="100%"/>
    </radialGradient>
    <radialGradient id="RadialGradient2" gradientUnits="objectBoundingBox" cx="0.5" cy="0.5" rx="0.5" y2="0.5" r="0.5" fr="0.25">
      <stop style="stop-color:#0000ff" offset="0%"/>
      <stop style="stop-color:#00ffff" offset="50%"/>
      <stop style="stop-color:#ffff00" offset="100%"/>
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>

  <g id="test-body-content" font-size="16">
    <rect x="20"  y="140" width="200" height="200" style="fill:url(#RadialGradient1)" />
    <rect x="260" y="140" width="200" height="200" style="fill:url(#RadialGradient2)" />
  </g>

</svg>
```

events.target_title: Feature fr gradient  (#508)

note.body:
Nice work! Nitpicking here, so feel free to ignore it - continuing from the discussion in the [issue](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/issues/508).

1. The presence of `fr` attribute or it not being equal to default imo is not a bulletproof way to determine that the SVG is of version 2.0. One can omit it or have it at the default `0.` and still expect it to behave per 2.0 spec.
1. The other potential problem is [float comparison](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17333/what-is-the-most-effective-way-for-float-and-double-comparison).

I'm sorry, this feature seemed like a low hanging newcomers fruit, but is really a can of worms.

PS. had no idea floats could be written as `0.`, thanks for the lesson.

events.target_title: Feature Request: Rotate Image.
Show download size in Updates

note.body:
Showing the size of the update could be quite valuable, for instance I recent used a network that had a 100GB a month cap on its internet connection. It would be nice to know that the update I’m about to download over my metered permanent connection is 2.8GB as many people have capped data limits even on their home/work internet connections. Neither #869 nor #877 provide an actual method to give people on such connections a chance to make an educated choice to download updates or abstain until they are next able to update. 

Also to second point of the bug poster quite a few people use the size of the update to know how long it might take. For instance on my home internet a 4GB file would take approximately 1 hour 15 minutes to download. If I needed to leave in a half hour I wouldn’t initiate that download until I had more time.

events.target_title: Add keyboard shortcuts for diff view and file tree view

note.body:
Hey, I'm trying to get prepared for the gsoc, and I'm trying to solve this issue.

So far what I've found is that we need to handle the shortcut through the on_key_pressed method in the Window class, since it first sees if key pressed can be handled by the search bar, and if not it defers the handling to the d_activities.current object which is of type GitgHistory.Activity or GitgCommit.Activity. 

I'm a little confused on how the plugins are loaded into the program, what I have understood so far is that the plugins are just the back-end implementation, and the UI for them are the GitgHistory.Activity, and GitgCommit.Activity. So this is where we might handle the key_pressing signal but I'm not sure if I'm correct.

events.target_title: Add keyboard shortcuts for diff view and file tree view

note.body:
I've checked the plugin classes but I didn't find a way to communicate with the application class to register or add the shortcut to the application ActionEntry like the other shortcuts.

I'm thinking about using the GMessageBus property in the GitgExt.Application Interface to communicate with the application but I'm not sure if this is the correct way.

events.target_title: Copy and paste stops working with "Broken pipe" error

note.body:
I can confirm that the issue is still live, and so common on Wayland that it makes it pretty much impractical to use the Gnome DE for everyday use.

@dboles I have the **GTK+ 3.24.13** (gtk3 1:3.24.13-1) installed (Arch Linux system up-to-date of today).

events.target_title: Pen Pressure Sensitivity

note.body:
Similar issue:

Windows 10.0.18362, x64
Microsoft Surface Pro 17986:
- Intel i5 7300U
- 8 GB RAM
Gimp 2.10.14
Bamboo Ink 2018

Pressure sensitivity works on native programs such as whiteboard, but Gimp does not see the pen as an input device in it's configuration options. Bamboo Ink is listed in the device manager:
- Bluetooth > Bamboo Ink
- Human Interface Devices > Bluetooth Low Energy GATT Compliant HID Device

Tried reinstalling both gimp and the pen. Additionally tried activating directX controller. Also tried installing other Wacom drivers. Did not install wintab.

Doesn't appear to have the same drivers as other Wacom tablets as attempting to install Wacom Drivers results in "No Tablet found on system" error.

As a work around would it be possible to capture bluetooth data and convert into a virtual device that GIMP would recognize through the GIMP-python API?

events.target_title: gdk/win32 should support other tablet API than WinTab

note.body: Hi @lb90, do you know if this issue is resolved in the experimental 3.0 build? I was hoping to test it out since I'm fairly confident this issue is preventing my stylus from having pressure sensitivity in GIMP.

events.target_title: Enhanced remote resource (image, movies, etc) whitelisting/blocking support

note.body:
I understand why automatically whitelisting senders that exist in the user's address book may be a desirable feature for many users, but I still feel it would be important to have a way to opt-out globally (this is an option, for example, in gmail: contacts are whitelisted by default, but it is possible to opt-out and decide about the loading of remote images in each single message). 

In my work, I interact with people who use services such as mailtrack dot io that use images to track if/when I open an email. Currently, if I use Geary, I have no way to check my email privately without sharing this information with them. Removing those contacts from my address book would be impractical, because, after all, I still need to contact them.

In brief, I feel this would be important to improve privacy protection (see also https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/issues/159).

events.target_title: Enhanced remote resource (image, movies, etc) whitelisting/blocking support

note.body: Yes, a preference such as the one you described would deal with my use case, that would be great!

Bring back plain color backgrounds

note.body:
@feaneron Would you mind to provide the exact way to change this setting via cli?

Also, i'd like to know which variant is the most easy on system ressources when going the image-only way available in current gnome:

a - Use a 1x1 - one by one - pixel dimensioned bitmap as:
    png | jpg | gif | bmp

b - Use a one-color-image in whatever dimensions as:
    png | jpg | gif | bmp

c - Use a one-color-image in a fixed dimension as:
    png | jpg | gif | bmp

    whereas the fixed dimension is based on:
    vga | svga | wsvga | wxvga | aspect-ratio

Or alternatively, if this is an option, using a SVG?

This has to be understood as an indirect question asking for specifics of the currently used process/routine for "painting" the background in Gnomes Background-Module. What would be the most compatible/future-proof variant and what the most performant one for the time being?

events.target_title: User-unfriendly behaviour of sliders in the Unsharp Mask dialogue
User-unfriendly behaviour of sliders in the Unsharp Mask dialogue

note.body:
I might agree with your opinion, but a) the maximum value is currently somehow arbitrary and b) the way it currently works requires experimenting to find out what the actually possible maximum value is.

One doesn't need high values for "normal" sharpening actions, of course, but once you need extreme sharpness in layer masks or dedicated layers for special purposes, the current functionality is a PITA. I actually stumbled across the issue while writing a tutorial in which I needed both a hyper-sharpened layer and a corresponding layer mask to fix an image with overexposed areas.

Messages until copy a CD
Messages until copy a CD

note.body: Thank you for your fast answer! My problem is, that I get a message that suggest that Brasero write data on a disk, during it read the disk. Since it is possible to rewrite or extend disks, I thought that Brasero damage my source disk, because I had select the wrong function.

events.target_title: Messages until copy a CD

note.body:
I think this message will be shown during reading a source CD:

#: ../libbrasero-burn/brasero-progress.c:505

msgid "Estimated drive speed:"

msgstr "Geschätzte Brenngeschwindigkeit:"

events.target_title: Meld crashes on Windows when changing keyboard layouts
Meld crashes on Windows when changing keyboard layouts
Meld crashes on Windows when changing keyboard layouts

note.body:
I did some searching and I indeed found a 1 year old GTK bug: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/1544 affecting GTK 3.24.2.

I think this is probably the underlying issue, as 3.24.2 is exactly the version which is bundled with the current windows releases.

Locking screen causes windows to be moved to other desktop / monitor

note.body:
I can confirm this happens as well, I'm also running F31 in Gnome on Wayland.  I'll also add that it seems to only happen when mixing port types.  For example, I have the following setup:

HDMI-1 = Dell 1600x900
DVI-1 = HP 1920x1080
DVI-2 = HP 1920x1080

With HDMI-1 plugged in when I lock the screen AND the displays go into power saving mode (power off) and then I unlock the screen the windows are a complete mess, presumably randomly scattered across the first screen to wake up.  If I disable HDMI-1 (unplug it from the desktop) then this problem goes away and my windows stay where they were before I locked the screen.  Let me know if I can provide any other info to help with this.

This might be related to [Cinnamon issue 5487](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/5487) and [Unity bug 1295267](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/unity/+bug/1295267)

If I disable HDMI-1 (unplug it from the desktop) then this problem goes away and my windows stay where they were before I locked the screen.  Let me know if I can provide any other info to help with this.

This might be related to [Cinnamon issue 5487](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/5487) and [Unity bug 1295267](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/unity/+bug/1295267)

events.target_title: Locking screen causes windows to be moved to other desktop / monitor

note.body:
I can confirm this happens as well, I'm also running F31 in Gnome on Wayland.  I'll also add that it seems to only happen when mixing port types.  For example, I have the following setup:

HDMI-1 = Dell 1600x900
DVI-1 = HP 1920x1080
DVI-2 = HP 1920x1080

With HDMI-1 plugged in when I lock the screen AND the displays go into power saving mode (power off) and then I unlock the screen the windows are a complete mess, presumably randomly scattered across the first screen to wake up.  If I disable HDMI-1 (unplug it from the desktop) then this problem goes away and my windows stay where they were before I locked the screen.  Let me know if I can provide any other info to help with this.

This might be related to [Cinnamon issue 5487](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/5487) and [Unity bug 1295267](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/unity/+bug/1295267)

events.target_title: click position is flipped to cursor position when in tent mode
click position is flipped to cursor position when in tent mode

note.body:
When I don't rotate anything at all the bug is still present

also, I used this doc:

https://wiki.ubuntu.com/X/InputCoordinateTransformation

I tried to rotate
 * the virtual core pointer (id=2)
 * the actual wireless mouse I use (id=9 in my case)
 * both of them at the same time

results:
either both the displayed cursor position and click position flipped (hence making them not to coincide again)
or none of them

this is a video I just made:

https://youtu.be/-BfWDUZtMhE (was cut to make it quicker, otherwise unedited, ubuntu 20.04, updated right before recording this video)

I still think there's a bug somewhere, the issue isn't that the accelerometer data is disregarded, the issue is that accelerometer data is applied selectively (or twice?) in some cases

Bind hotkeys with Super key didn't work in GTK3 apps

note.body:
I had the exact same problem for the very same task, using Gtk+3.24.10 on Mate desktop.

The toolkit seems to silently ignore **<Super>** bindings, which is not very nice to the user. Super is not considered by GdkX11Keymap to be a modifier on PRIMARY_ACCELERATOR or NO_TEXT_INPUT intents. However there are no warning or errors when you try to use it in a css file.

Here is a patch that fixes it.[fix-super-bindings.patch](/uploads/fe84ef7bae7e947a6fe70a96645ef4e8/fix-super-bindings.patch)

Add Python 3 support

note.body:
For the [LiGurOS](https://gitlab.com/liguros) distribution I have applied patches to the sources of the 1.1.34 release of libxslt.

Tests with gitlab for various python versions were successful in compiling. The results of the test can be found [here](https://gitlab.com/liguros/qa/pipelines/116193610).

Ebuild and patches are [here](https://gitlab.com/liguros/kit-fixups/-/tree/develop/core-kit/curated/dev-libs/libxslt), with the patch files in the "files" subdirectory. Each patch file is for one source file, except for the tests patch, which contains the changes to the files in the python/tests subdirectory.

Ebuild and patches are [here](https://gitlab.com/liguros/kit-fixups/-/tree/develop/core-kit/curated/dev-libs/libxslt), with the patch files in the "files" subdirectory. Each patch file is for one source file, except for the tests patch, which contains the changes to the files in the python/tests subdirectory.

note.body:
This issue is still there, seen the same error today. Will test whether installing `libcairo2-dev` changes anything. If so, perhaps meson should tell me about it being missing.

**Edit:** Installing the `libcairo2-dev` did not help. Perhaps it does not help when installing into `/usr/local/` as prefix using `LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib/ meson --prefix=/usr/local/ ../goi_build`.

Do we need to install cairo into the prefix as well?

**Edit 2:** No, even building cairo and installing cairo into the same prefix does not help, still the same error:

``` shell
<path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: symbol lookup error: <path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: undefined symbol: g_number_parser_error_quark
```

**Edit 3:** Rebuilding GLib after installing cairo into the prefix does not get rid of the problem either. I am out of ideas currently.

So now suddenly libgio has problems, although I installed it by installing the latest stable glib ...

I was going to create a guide on how to compile everything for using gtk+3 in a Python environment, but I lost track now of all the things I tried and the guide would have to be tested in a virtual machine or something. This is quite frustrating, because the only guides I can find are in outdated documentation of the GNOME project or linuxfromscratch, but they are also incomplete and often assume things being installed or reference non-existent files in up to date versions of libraries. There is also no clear instruction on whether to use meson and ninja, or the classical configure, make, make install dance. If there was just one comprehensive guide to building all these libraries somewhere, so that people could easily figure it all out, without being an expert in compiling libraries or GNOME itself ...

So now suddenly libgio has problems, although I installed it by installing the latest stable glib ...

I was going to create a guide on how to compile everything for using gtk+3 in a Python environment, but I lost track now of all the things I tried and the guide would have to be tested in a virtual machine or something. This is quite frustrating, because the only guides I can find are in outdated documentation of the GNOME project or linuxfromscratch, but they are also incomplete and often assume things being installed or reference non-existent files in up to date versions of libraries. There is also no clear instruction on whether to use meson and ninja, or the classical configure, make, make install dance. If there was just one comprehensive guide to building all these libraries somewhere, so that people could easily figure it all out, without being an expert in compiling libraries or GNOME itself ...

note.body:
This issue is still there, seen the same error today. Will test whether installing `libcairo2-dev` changes anything. If so, perhaps meson should tell me about it being missing.

**Edit:** Installing the `libcairo2-dev` did not help. Perhaps it does not help when installing into `/usr/local/` as prefix using `LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib/ meson --prefix=/usr/local/ ../goi_build`.

Do we need to install cairo into the prefix as well?

**Edit 2:** No, even building cairo and installing cairo into the same prefix does not help, still the same error:

``` shell
<path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: symbol lookup error: <path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: undefined symbol: g_number_parser_error_quark
```

**Edit 3:** Rebuilding GLib after installing cairo into the prefix does not get rid of the problem either. I am out of ideas currently.

So now suddenly libgio has problems, although I installed it by installing the latest stable glib ...

I was going to create a guide on how to compile everything for using gtk+3 in a Python environment, but I lost track now of all the things I tried and the guide would have to be tested in a virtual machine or something. This is quite frustrating, because the only guides I can find are in outdated documentation of the GNOME project or linuxfromscratch, but they are also incomplete and often assume things being installed or reference non-existent files in up to date versions of libraries. There is also no clear instruction on whether to use meson and ninja, or the classical configure, make, make install dance. If there was just one comprehensive guide to building all these libraries somewhere, so that people could easily figure it all out, without being an expert in compiling libraries or GNOME itself ...

note.body:
This issue is still there, seen the same error today. Will test whether installing `libcairo2-dev` changes anything. If so, perhaps meson should tell me about it being missing.

**Edit:** Installing the `libcairo2-dev` did not help. Perhaps it does not help when installing into `/usr/local/` as prefix using `LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib/ meson --prefix=/usr/local/ ../goi_build`.

Do we need to install cairo into the prefix as well?

**Edit 2:** No, even building cairo and installing cairo into the same prefix does not help, still the same error:

``` shell
<path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: symbol lookup error: <path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: undefined symbol: g_number_parser_error_quark
```

**Edit 3:** Rebuilding GLib after installing cairo into the prefix does not get rid of the problem either. I am out of ideas currently.

So now suddenly libgio has problems, although I installed it by installing the latest stable glib ...

I was going to create a guide on how to compile everything for using gtk+3 in a Python environment, but I lost track now of all the things I tried and the guide would have to be tested in a virtual machine or something. This is quite frustrating, because the only guides I can find are in outdated documentation of the GNOME project or linuxfromscratch, but they are also incomplete and often assume things being installed or reference non-existent files in up to date versions of libraries. There is also no clear instruction on whether to use meson and ninja, or the classical configure, make, make install dance. If there was just one comprehensive guide to building all these libraries somewhere, so that people could easily figure it all out, without being an expert in compiling libraries or GNOME itself ...

undefined symbol: g_ number_parser_error_quark when building with meson

note.body:
This issue is still there, seen the same error today. Will test whether installing `libcairo2-dev` changes anything. If so, perhaps meson should tell me about it being missing.

**Edit:** Installing the `libcairo2-dev` did not help. Perhaps it does not help when installing into `/usr/local/` as prefix using `LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib/ meson --prefix=/usr/local/ ../goi_build`.

Do we need to install cairo into the prefix as well?

**Edit 2:** No, even building cairo and installing cairo into the same prefix does not help, still the same error:

``` shell
<path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: symbol lookup error: <path to build dir>/goi_build/tmp-introspect05ecq_tq/GLib-2.0: undefined symbol: g_number_parser_error_quark
```

**Edit 3:** Rebuilding GLib after installing cairo into the prefix does not get rid of the problem either. I am out of ideas currently.

**Edit 4:** I do not know how exactly I did it, but some combination of rebuilding glib and trying to build gobject-introspection again multiple times got me a little further (or perhaps less far?):

events.target_title: Make the Dash visible when no window touching it

I like the default.

It keeps my desktop nice and clear for my apps.

I want a new app I hit super, type three letters and hit return and it opens.

I like how gnome does not keep flashing the tool bar every time my mouse goes near it.

events.target_title: [UX] Hide HeaderBar when full screen mode is entered

note.body: I observe the same problem with version 3.34.2. This bug is especially irritating because, as far as I can see, hiding the header bar is the only thing in Evince that cannot be done using the keyboard. So after going to fullscreen using F11, the user has to switch to the mouse just to get rid of the header bar.

events.target_title: "Account problem" on Fedora when in background
"Account problem" on Fedora when in background
"Account problem" on Fedora when in background

note.body:
Hey guys, thank you for your responses, first of all, this is a screenshot that shows the whole window (the color of the warning messages is due to the theme I am using):

![Screenshot_from_2020-02-11_06-31-02](/uploads/f637facf713c7d42c1bfb5501cafc34d/Screenshot_from_2020-02-11_06-31-02.png)

And when I click on Details I get this:

```
Account identifier: goa_account_1574280752_0
```

events.target_title: Show more WiFi info in Connection Info dialog
Show more WiFi info in Connection Info dialog

note.body:
Well, kinda, but not really. Sure, you can gleam all that info from syslog or tools like `iw`. But IMO the info is basic enough that it should be easily accessible via GUI too.

If you're worried about cluttering the dialog, you could remove Speed instead, as that info is pretty much useless in 99% of all cases. Adding Link Quality/Signal Level and Channel would suffice, I think.

Cheers!

text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text
text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text

note.body:
While resizing, the terminals behave like this:
**gnome-terminal**
does not resize text, only resizes the window, this is a huge annoyance, since gnome-termial in most other regards is quite good. Text resize is, for my part, mostly used to highlight some text snippet on a 13" 4k monitor, for colleagues, because it's hard to see the text at great distances with that resolution. When this is done, I have to resize the window, to get the text larger, then manually resize the window back down to it's original size, due to it otherwise blocking the other windows on the screen.
**Terminology**
Text resize as expected, snaps the window to the nearest whole character size.
**Terminator**
Resizes the text, if it doesn't fit perfectly with a intiger value of characters, then there is a small gap on the far side.

events.target_title: text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text
text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text

note.body:
Btw. I don't care if the window resizes smoothly or flips a few px on each resize, as long as the window size is approx the same and the text size changes in the expected direction.
In other words, I care about the functionality, and much less about the aesthetics(Shiny doesn't always equal practical and productive.

events.target_title: text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text

note.body:
Thanks for you constructive reply.
Terminology also takes original size into account, so if you resize alot, it will keep within a fraction of a character-width.

As a consultant on the go, I find that the best compromise between weight and screen-realestate is to have a 13" laptop with 4k screen + an asus zenscreen 1080p, this makes for some resizing scenarios, in adition to my first example.
At the office, I'm just fine with a 34" and if that was all I had to use, I wouldn't have created this issue :)

I find it quite interesting how you describe the aesthetics in relation to being productive. I get the same feeling, but with "cludder" actions, such as having to readjust windows, because I for some reason need the text in it to be a different size for some time.

Firefox and Chromium also resize the content of the window without changing the size of the window itself.

I know that Gnome stereotypicly want to avoid any options if at all possible, but would there be a chance to add an option to not resize the window when the text is resized ?

Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10
Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10

note.body:
Yesterday I downloaded what I assumed to be the latest version of GIMP
2.10.12 off of the GIMP website,  as I stated in my query. Is there
something newer than that?

events.target_title: Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10

note.body:
Well, it had GIMP in the URL, so I assumed it was you guys. I just used a
different search terminology and came up with the version you mentioned. I
uninstalled version 2.10.12 as I downloaded 2.10.14. I then installed it
and opened it up. I still have no Toolbox. Tried Ctrl+B and Tools/Toolbox
and got nothing. But this time I was able to get the user's manual.
However,  it doesn't appear to have a search box for Settings. I did a Find
on the Index page and was not able to find it. Is there any way to reload
the original settings or something?

events.target_title: Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10

note.body: I don't know if it's a Windows 10 thing because it's done some bad things to my data, like deleting entire folders I have been working on (twice). I don't delete folders I'm working on. All I know is that one day the Toolbar was there, the next time I brought it up , it was gone and hasn't been seen since. That's with 3 uploads now.

events.target_title: Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10

note.body:
I also thought they might be hidden, but I'm not sure what you mean by the
tab key. If you mean Alt+Tab to change windows, I've tried that. Could it
be hidden somewhere in the GIMP program? If so, how would I find iy?
Thanks.

events.target_title: Can't get the Toolbox to show up in Windows 10

note.body:
I see what you mean. I pressed the Tab key while in GIMP, and nothing
happened. Then I pressed the Tab key a whole bunch of times in quick
succession and a whole bunch of things popped up, including the Toolbox.
Thank you. I would have never thought of that. Now I just hope it stays. If
it doesn't, I know how to get it back. Thank you very much.

note.body:
The version of GTK that I have is 3.24.5-1 (Debian Stable package libgtk-3-0).

I installed the following debug symbol packages:
 - libgtk-3-0-dbgsym - 3.24.5-1
 - libpango-1.0-0-dbgsym - 1.42.4-7~deb10u1
 - libcairo2-dbgsym - 1.16.0-4
 - libx11-6-dbgsym - 2:1.6.7-1
 - libglib2.0-0-dbgsym - 2.58.3-2+deb10u2
 - libffi6-dbg - 3.2.1-9
 - python3-gi-dbg - 3.30.4-1

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.2 becomes really slow from time to time

note.body:
I got to that point too. (using GIMP 2.10.14)
The loading of the file with lots of grouped layers took longer and longer.
Also changing a layer took more time the further down in the layer tree it is placed. Editing the topmost layer in no layer sub group is nearly instant.
Since I figured this out I keep "[ ] Enable layer group previews" disabled to be able to edit my UHD textures faster.
(Setting in Edit > Preferences > Interface aka "User Interface" > Previews)

Reproduce: Use large files with "Enable layer group previews" enabled. 
E.g. Import, convert and play around with the layers of this UHD textures: https://forums.eagle.ru/showpost.php?p=3837660

I dunno what function is used to calculate the preview but it blocks the whole interface and may lead to a windows grey out (not responding window) unless the calculations are done. The preview is quite nice tho. This make me think it is not just some simple pixel matrix of the preview collecting the nearest pixels of the big layers but maybe a detailed downsapling method calculating all the UHD changes of all the layers step by step.
A simpler function and maybe a asynchronus calculation for the layer preview (or a setting to choose both) would be very nice.

this issue might be relatet to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/2283 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/1293

events.target_title: [BZ#653323] librsvg-2.34.0 rdepends on gtk+-3 automagically

note.body:
Seems like this defect can be closed since the rsvg-view has been removed as have the gtk3 hard-coded bits of configure:

commit 522aeee0ca9b4ff3940bea2d13ebb77ec6c064a6
Author: Federico Mena Quintero <federico@gnome.org>
Date:   Tue Jul 2 13:06:33 2019

    Remove GTK3 bits from configure.ac

commit 44f8524f4492b7d91c2360a12843a66efe9f04fd
Author: Federico Mena Quintero <federico@gnome.org>
Date:   Tue Jul 2 12:58:56 2019

    Remove rsvg-view.c and its Makefile stuff
    
    Rsvg-view is a pretty crappy SVG viewer.
    
    Also, it adds a GTK dependency on librsvg.  This makes the whole
    dependency graph awkward, since GTK indirectly depends on librsvg via
    gdk-pixbuf.
    
    I think we are better off encouraging people to use image viewers that
    are actually well-written and pleasant to use, like EOG.

Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body: I would love to have this too. Can this be done as an experimental feature and off by default? I would use it even if it's not super complete. I suspect most of my incoming emails (composed by outlook) are simple enough to be covered by a quick scan of the html body.

events.target_title: Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body: Thanks for the quick change! Can't wait to try it out.

events.target_title: Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body:
BTW, I agree that heuristics would be too tricky to play with. I tried the firefox extension mentioned above and got mixed results. Certain web pages don't look well no matter what strategy I choose from the extension. Without heuristics, the unset all option you added would be the most useful one for people who take the consistency to the system dark theme as top priority. The next best thing would be to change the text color only if there isn't one set explicitly already, as the oringal post suggested. It could end up with black on black for some emails, but it would preserve extra highlighting colors for other emails. In my emails, text showing black right now is just wrapped by: `

` Nothing else. Text in replied email or highlighted is surrounded by something like: `

` or `

` I know I am asking for too much within 24 hours :stuck_out_tongue: Just something to consider. Thanks.

events.target_title: Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body: One more thing to mention. The outlook web interface does a pretty good job of keeping colored text readable on a dark background. Still, they kept the option to turn the background back to white temporarily. It's a button on each individual mail title bar where the reply/forward buttons are. They call it "turn on the lights". My guess is that there is always gonna be some kind of color combination that doesn't translate well with the conversion function. This "light switch" seems to be a reasonable solution to cover those edge cases.

This "light switch" seems to be a reasonable solution to cover those edge cases.

events.target_title: Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body: Thanks for the quick change! Can't wait to try it out.

events.target_title: Option to unset colors provided in HTML mails for preview

note.body:
BTW, I agree that heuristics would be too tricky to play with. I tried the firefox extension mentioned above and got mixed results. Certain web pages don't look well no matter what strategy I choose from the extension. Without heuristics, the unset all option you added would be the most useful one for people who take the consistency to the system dark theme as top priority. The next best thing would be to change the text color only if there isn't one set explicitly already, as the oringal post suggested. It could end up with black on black for some emails, but it would preserve extra highlighting colors for other emails. In my emails, text showing black right now is just wrapped by: `

` Nothing else. Text in replied email or highlighted is surrounded by something like: `

` or `

` I know I am asking for too much within 24 hours :stuck_out_tongue: Just something to consider. Thanks.

Support shortcut keys for open/close directories

note.body:
I vote for this, while using the shift modifier works to open/close folders, I (and possibly many others) am very familiar with using all 4 cursor keys, without shift, to navigate tree-view widgets in GTK desktops.
With that in mind, the close folder action should work when a child is selected, if the child is an open folder, the child folder should be close on first press, then the parent on the second press.

My preference would be to not need the shift modifier for this, as this is more inline with ncdu, and nearly every other tree navigator i've come across... but this could always be a user setting!

events.target_title: New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body: I just switched to a new Ubuntu version and realized (a bit late) that the type-ahead feature is no longer the norm. I'm all in favor of bringing type-ahead back or having a way to let the user choose the desired behavior. And as an example of how important is this navigational feature is, consider the file saving dialog. Right now, when you save a file, you can use the type-ahead feature to quickly move to the destination directory. This implementation has not changed. So now there is an inconsistency for the user. When saving a file I can use type-ahead. But when using nautilus to check a folder content, type-ahead does not work.

events.target_title: Make allow-links-change-zoom false by default

note.body: How long will we wait for that day? 7 months seems long enough. It might be part of the specification but that does not mean the current behavior is desirable. Until there is a discoverable UI for changing this (ie a popup toolbar when you follow such link) it should just be off. In my experience these zoom flags are only document authoring error and did not find any document where they bring any value.

events.target_title: Make allow-links-change-zoom false by default

note.body: [0001-gschema-default-allow-links-change-zoom-to-false.patch](/uploads/708fd9ee3d85b07211d0ce48607bfc62/0001-gschema-default-allow-links-change-zoom-to-false.patch)

events.target_title: Make allow-links-change-zoom false by default

note.body: yes, this does the bare minimum to fix the issue. I personally don't find any value in supporting this part of the PDF standard. I could craft a toy PDF that makes use of the link zoom flags but can't imagine any real world use case. The flags provided by the standard are unusable and when used it's user mistake and not intention.

events.target_title: font-size not computed correctly from parent element
font-size not computed correctly from parent element

note.body:
rsvg-convert is now working OK.

About the text size, it could be something related to the font size in class ".st2" defined in "em"
What is the default font size used by librsvg? Is there some way to set it like we can set the default DPI by using `rsvg_set_default_dpi`?

If I add the following CSS 

`g { font-size: 12pt }`

I expect the button font size to increase, but it doesn't increase when it is rendered with librsvg.

Here's the output from Chrome:

![StandardDeviationButton.svg](/uploads/315ba3e7d0f359d8ad8e48949c6e5440/StandardDeviationButton.svg)

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions
font-size not computed correctly from parent element

note.body:
Thanks! In this case the default font-size is not an issue. 
The SVG element has `class="st3"` where `font-size:12px`. The text element has `class="st2"` where `font-size:0.833336em`. Since there are no other font-sizes defined on text element parents, the resulting font-size shall be 12*0.833336

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions

note.body:
It is attached, right click on the bargraph image and Save Link As...

Maybe on line 770 in drawing_ctx.rs the code could be replaced with something like `Ok(child_surface)`

The current code seems to fill the rect with white.

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions

note.body:
By filter chain I understand something like that:

`<rect x="20" y="20" width="100" height="100" fill="#ff0000" filter="url(#blur) url(#hue-rotate)"/>`

Here's a sample "filter chain" file from gecko tests:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/master/layout/reftests/svg/filters/svg-filter-chains/simple-chain.svg

But the specification doesn't say anything about that other object's styles like fill, stroke, etc. shall be ignored if a filter definition is missing. It is just about the filter and the filter chain.

So the attached file is rendered in Chrome, but not in Firefox.

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions
font-size not computed correctly from parent element

note.body:
Thanks! In this case the default font-size is not an issue. 
The SVG element has `class="st3"` where `font-size:12px`. The text element has `class="st2"` where `font-size:0.833336em`. Since there are no other font-sizes defined on text element parents, the resulting font-size shall be 12*0.833336

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions

note.body:
It is attached, right click on the bargraph image and Save Link As...

Maybe on line 770 in drawing_ctx.rs the code could be replaced with something like `Ok(child_surface)`

The current code seems to fill the rect with white.

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions

note.body:
By filter chain I understand something like that:

`<rect x="20" y="20" width="100" height="100" fill="#ff0000" filter="url(#blur) url(#hue-rotate)"/>`

Here's a sample "filter chain" file from gecko tests:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/master/layout/reftests/svg/filters/svg-filter-chains/simple-chain.svg

But the specification doesn't say anything about that other object's styles like fill, stroke, etc. shall be ignored if a filter definition is missing. It is just about the filter and the filter chain.

So the attached file is rendered in Chrome, but not in Firefox.

events.target_title: Provide easy access to the "Enter Location" feature/mode of Nautilus for the new user

note.body:
Ctrl+L feature is good but it is hidden and keyboard only.
It would be nice to be able to do the same think with mouse, and to discover it without googling.
`org.gnome.nautilus.preferences always-use-location-entry` isn't the same, it forces the application in one mode only, while the breadcrumb and the location copy/edit location mode are both critical features.

events.target_title: Provide easy access to the "Enter Location" feature/mode of Nautilus for the new user

note.body:
Use cases :
- I want to go to a location a colleague gave me on slack/I found on a forum. I don't know about Ctrl+L. I have to go manually to the correct path instead of a simple right-click -> paste.
- I want to send a relative directory path from nautilus to someone. I go to the directory, right click on the breadcrumb, then click "copy" (doesn't exists). I enter edit location bar, then select only the part I want and right-click > copy.
- I want to go to a file opened in an IDE which doesn't have the feature to open a file in nautilus. I copy a relative path (to the project), then open nautilus at the project location, copy/paste the path and edit the path (with the keyboard) if necessary before validating.

Most of these actions could be done using only mouse.

note.body:
An update on this:
Apparently it seems to work already - at least partially.

Directly setting the string "Super_L" (no <> around) in dconf seems to the trick, well at least in GNOME Classic 3.34.

So it just seems to be an UI issue that it doesn't let to set the key.


Additionally though, I still haven't found a working way to use the keypad keys.

events.target_title: allow to use just <Super> in keybindings

note.body:
Interestingly: some keypad keys seem to work... e.g. I can set "Begin (keypad)" (in the control centre) and it launches e.g. my browser, while the "normal" Begin key doesn't.

The control centre even allows me to choose "Page Up (keybad)"... it's just that nothing happens when I press it ;-)

events.target_title: allow to use just <Super> in keybindings

note.body:
Ignore the last comment... the problem seems to be rather that my gnome-screensaver doesn't launch.

So I see the following "issues" remaining here:
- allow users to select just "Super_L" in the GUI, which works nicely at last in GNOME Classic mode
- if it doesn't work already in GNOME Shell (non classic mode), cause <Super> is handled specially it would be nice to allow users switching keys there too

Thanks :-)

events.target_title: Display (perhaps entire machine) locks up when I try to use DisplayLink with Wayland

note.body:
I can confirm this happening on Opensuse Tumbleweed with Gnome 3.34 and Kernel 5.5.1-1-default.
HARDWARE: Samsung NP350XAA laptop connected do a Dell D3100 dock. 
This laptop has Intel integraqted graphics and a discrete NVIDIA GPU which is not in use (proprietary drivers nor nouveau even installed on the system).

SOFTWARE:
EVDI as checked out from git on Feb 10 2020 (based on 1.6.4) and Displaylink 1.6.4 downloaded from the displaylink-rpm project hosted on github.

THE ISSUE:
Usually only the display hangs and I'm still able to ssh into the system and kill the gnome-shell session.
What triggers the crash/hang/freeze is closing the laptop's lid or disabling the builtin display on display settings. Ie. any action that results in the Displaylink display being the only active display.
Dmesg throws a kernel oops, since I'm on a fresh reboot will have to re-trigger the crash now and post here soon afterwards.

events.target_title: Display (perhaps entire machine) locks up when I try to use DisplayLink with Wayland

note.body:
I have reproduced the issue and attached the dmesg output. Although it is possible to restart a graphical interface with sddm over wayland, the entire system becomes unstable (for example, this time the screen froze again after entering my password and hitting enter on sddm login screen).

GIMP doesn't properly remove image data when an alpha channel is supported

note.body:
There is no way to truly **delete** a pixel (selection) from the common bitmap formats. To keep the image consistently rectangular and gapless, every pixel needs to have a RGBA value (OK, with floating point values one could save NaNs, but I digress...). So words like **delete**, **erase**, etc. are *all* misleading if taken verbatim. Consequentially, one has to realize that **erase** will just set some or all of the RGBA values of the pixels (in the selection) to a predefined value.

I am torn whether the GIMP project should assume that users of its software have such basic understanding of how image formats and tools work. Though I'd err on the side that if you have "simple" needs, use "simple" tools, or spend time to learn the tools you want to use. On the other hand, non-surprising defaults are also a good idea for such a project. Is it more worthwhile to keep the default behavior in the way its current users got used to and expect, or make it more "safe" for new users with the specific need to redact parts of an image?

events.target_title: Mouse wheel zoom without modifier, preferences checkbox

note.body:
I am a paraplegic, and working with two hands at the same time is an effort.
A setting like this in Preferences would come in **very** 'handy'.

Edit:
Actually what I also meant is: releasing the mouse to hit '+' or '-' is very awkward. Btw., my other hand/arm is supporting my position all this time, so has to be taken out of the equation.

And finally: I came here because I was trying to see if I can add a **default** zoom factor of 60%; I am presently scanning a lot of documents that for me have an optimal zoom factor at 60%. Maybe we could add an option in Preferences to add a **custom** **default** zoom factor?

Sorry, I was just trying to report it real quick and move on and didn't give all info...

Git hook is executable and is a simple test case for now however my setup may be a little unusual:
 - My hook is in a custom .hooks folder setup in the git config.
 - My hook is executed by php, note the shebang.
 - My hook is executable and works with GitHub desktop
(altho GitHub desktop is no longer available as a snap hence I tried gitg)

Info you asked for with test commit:

```
#!/usr/bin/env php
<?php
echo "some error\n";
exit(1);
```



```
┌[0]-[brad@ubuntu]-[08:29 AM]-[CHMS-3302 +]
└[ ~/repo/docker/web-app ]>git status
On branch CHMS-3302
Your branch is ahead of 'origin/CHMS-3302' by 1 commit.
  (use "git push" to publish your local commits)

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

        modified:   .hooks/pre-commit

┌[0]-[brad@ubuntu]-[08:29 AM]-[CHMS-3302 +]
└[ ~/repo/docker/web-app ]>git commit -m "test"
some error
┌[1]-[brad@ubuntu]-[08:29 AM]-[CHMS-3302 +]
└[ ~/repo/docker/web-app ]>git status
On branch CHMS-3302
Your branch is ahead of 'origin/CHMS-3302' by 1 commit.
  (use "git push" to publish your local commits)

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

        modified:   .hooks/pre-commit

┌[0]-[brad@ubuntu]-[08:29 AM]-[CHMS-3302 +]
└[ ~/repo/docker/web-app ]>gitg --version
gitg 3.26.0
```


Works form CLI but gitg gui does not execute the hook and commits successfully.

events.target_title: Gimp crashes Xorg on HiDPI screen

note.body:
I have the exact same problem with GIMP running on a Dell XPS 15 9560 with a 3840x2160 display.

Using $ nvidia-settings

and changing the PRIME profile from Nvidia (Performance Mode) to Intel (Power Saving) stops the problem but then I lose hardware acceleration.

Other apps crash Xorg the exact same way as well, including a game called "Pathway" on Steam. If the application is full screen a hard reset is required as there is absolutely no way for Xorg to recover. If the application is windowed, Xorg recovers to the login screen.

It may seem unreleated but I have dumps and DMESG logs [available here](https://steamcommunity.com/app/546430/discussions/0/3620268358831092266/). Maybe this will help someone out.

events.target_title: Bring back file name copy/paste functionality in GTK file chooser
Bring back file name copy/paste functionality in GTK file chooser

note.body:
I know it is still there, as I realized after many frustrating hours, but the extra key stroke, with zero visual cue, has left countless people, not just me, frustrated, evident from numerous reports (see the google search links in my post). That's a lot of person-hours.

I don't know why folder-level navigation deserves to exclusively take that precious space - it is already easily achievable by 1) if moving down-ward, double-clicking a sub-folder name or Alt+Right, and 2) if moving up-ward, use the back/up button or Alt+Up. What's really missing is the ability to directly copy/paste (and telling people where to copy/paste), which allows people to switch to a completely different path rapidly (actually, for me, over 80% cases fall under that category, because I almost never save/open files from the default folder positions; also I almost never use Ctrl+C but the mid-mouse-key). 

Here is Windows's file browser. When someone clicks on the empty part of folder navigation buttons, it automatically turns the field into an edit box. That's still much more intuitive/efficient than replying on the folder-level buttons alone to navigate.

![windows_folder_navigation](/uploads/c085b0d95b3ba9f3448f04555d98c2f2/windows_folder_navigation.png)

events.target_title: Selection tool issues bug
Composer: Signature and reply editing UI

note.body:
A related issue is the order of reply quote and signature: Other clients, e.g. Thunderbird, put the signature below the reply quote. This seems to be reasonable to me for two reasons:

1. It is customary for e-mail clients to use "-- " as a signature delimiter. Many client programs treat all text below that delimiter as a signature: It is often visually distinguished from the main text (e.g. dimmed), and/or stripped from replies. If Geary puts the signature above the reply quote, other clients (and actually, Geary itself) treat the quote as part of the signature.

2. If one wants to reply in-between the quoted text, a signature before the quote is disturbing.

    ```
    Hey Florence,

    On Sat, Feb 15, 2020 at 12:53, Florence Smith <florence@smith.org> wrote:
    > How would next Thursday work for you?

    Next Thursday sounds great! See you then!

    Monica

    -- 
    Monica Meyer
    Head of Research
    ```

    vs

    ```
    Hey Florence,

    -- 
    Monica Meyer
    Head of Research

    On Sat, Feb 15, 2020 at 12:53, Florence Smith <florence@smith.org> wrote:
    > How would next Thursday work for you?

    Next Thursday sounds great! See you then!

    Monica
    ```

events.target_title: GIMP crashed with a fatal error: fatal error: unhandled exception
Please add support for ssh-add -c (ask confirmation for every use of key)

note.body:
I'm also interested in this; for the past few years, I've been using `gpg-agent` instead of `gnome-keyring-daemon` for this purpose by overriding `SSH_AUTH_SOCK` in my `.zshenv`:

```
export SSH_AUTH_SOCK="$(gpgconf --list-dirs agent-ssh-socket)"
```

I was curious whether `gnome-keyring-daemon` (gnome-keyring 3.28.0.2-1ubuntu1.18.04.1 from Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS) could do this now, so I removed my override and added my key with `ssh-add -c`. And while it didn't immediately work, something was obviously different, so `ssh-add -c` did seem to have an effect:

```
sign_and_send_pubkey: signing failed: agent refused operation
```

I killed my running `gnome-keyring-daemon` process and started it as a foreground process, where the problem became obvious:

```
martin@dogmeat ~ % gnome-keyring-daemon -f
SSH_AUTH_SOCK=/run/user/1000/keyring/ssh
Gkm-Message: 15:51:46.486: using old keyring directory: /home/martin/.gnome2/keyrings
Gkm-Message: 15:51:46.486: using old keyring directory: /home/martin/.gnome2/keyrings
** Message: 15:52:00.371: the /usr/bin/ssh-add command failed: Der Kindprozess wurde mit Status 1 beendet
ssh_askpass: exec(/usr/bin/ssh-askpass): No such file or directory

(ssh-askpass:394): Gtk-WARNING **: 15:53:53.922: Theme parsing error: gtk-widgets.css:1214:18: Not using units is deprecated. Assuming 'px'.

(ssh-askpass:413): Gtk-WARNING **: 15:54:00.808: Theme parsing error: gtk-widgets.css:1214:18: Not using units is deprecated. Assuming 'px'.
```

After I installed the `ssh-askpass-gnome` package, confirmation works now :tada:

This might have been fixed by 8db2b978e485d7349a46c734dd51fc30196da01a - apparently `gnome-keyring-daemon` now no longer has its own SSH agent implementation, but just wraps `ssh-agent`.
